The pledge of 4,166,667 shares by the [Wirecard] CEO on 19th December 2017 came on the day the stock closed at €93.65. Earlier this month the stock touched an intraday low of €91.46 and reached a closing low of €96.86. Would there be a margin call if the stock starts trading below the strike price of the pledge? We don’t know the mechanics of the transaction or the use of proceeds of course, but we do know that €390 million of stock is a large sum and the pledge equates to 48% of stock owned by the CEO.

BE11:29am

AQ reminder that Footasylum's problems are largely self inflicted, as per Peel Hunt from about six months ago.

BE11:29am

Current trading is very poor but it’s not just the market: Clearly the summer
has been a difficult one for most retailers, but July and August’s trading has
caused Footasylum to downgrade its LfL assumptions for the full year. It isn’t
down solely to the market though; far from it. The news that the apparel buy has
been poor will have been a major contributory factor, and it also appears that the
company was overly bullish of its ability to mark down the heavy stock holding
in some footwear lines (“we can’t give them away”). So we now have a situation
where some of both the shoes and the clothes in the stores are in need of marking
down (and more importantly are not going to draw anybody in, something that
will take months to fix). The footwear issues are common to most retailers, but
the apparel offer has deteriorated for a number of reasons. We suspect that the
buyers, whilst having decent access to the big brands, have made the odd misselection.
Additionally some of the brands that FOOT has helped to develop
(such as Gym King for example), but are not exclusive, have become increasingly
available elsewhere (GK can be found on ASOS and Amazon amongst others).
So management’s heavily reduced guidance is down more to fundamental issues
with the offer, rather than purely nerves about the consumer.

CockneyRebel FOOT still have £5m cash I believe too
BE11:30am

And again from last month.

DJ @1st why shouldn't people have the right to bet on shares falling as well as rising?
11:30 am
BE11:30am

It is clear that to generate this satisfactory level of sales
growth, management has had to be very aggressive in discounting and
promotions. It has been known for a while that Footasylum had an unenviable
stock position as a function of some injudicious buying decisions on both
footwear and apparel, and in order to sell this through it is clear that a greater
discount has been required than expected. We were forecasting an H2 gross
margin that was down by 100 bps but the reality is that it will be down by nearer
300. That obviously leaves quite a dent in gross profit, but on a more positive
note, the heavy lifting has now been done on inventory and the stock file is now
much cleaner.
Another downgrade. We took c20% off our EBITDA numbers last week but it
is very difficult to hold even our new numbers on the basis of such a troubled
gross margin. Management is suggesting that it is beginning a cost saving
programme: that is going to have to click into place very quickly if our new
number is going to be delivered, and we don’t actually sense that Footasylum was
a “fat” business in the first place: we fear that taking cost out could impact
customer service standards and reduce the amount that is available for marketing.
That’s not a spiral management will want to get on, and the trick here is going to
be to generate some underlying LFL sales growth without recourse to lower gross
margins. That won’t be easy, given the competitive landscape and the probability
that news like today’s doesn’t help relationships with the big suppliers. We are
taking £0.5m off our outer year numbers, but over time we will need more
chapter and verse on strategic direction.

BornCynic oops - fat finger. -27.7% down for 2018.
wayneJ @1st Lt - I think what damages is companies at false prices. The issue is whether there is any material issues that BaFin is aware of or ought to be aware of that are creating a false market in the price. It would have been very easy for BaFin to have said that they have been in touch directly with the Singaporean investigation and they believe that there are no material issues. They have not said that - did they even bother is the issue.

Plus500, a leading online service provider for trading Contracts for Difference ("CFDs") internationally, notes recent press commentary surrounding its annual report and accounts for the year ended 31 December 2017 ("2017 Accounts").

Plus500 confirms that there was a drafting error on page 44 of the 2017 Accounts. The 2017 Accounts state that "In 2017, as in 2016 and 2015, the Company did not generate net revenues or losses from market P&L". The words "or losses" in this statement were included erroneously. Since the publication of the 2017 Accounts, the Company has disclosed in the preliminary results announcement for the year ended 31 December 2018, issued on 12 February 2019, Plus500 suffered a negative revenue impact of $103 million in the 2017 financial year due to strong client trading performance, particularly in the final quarter of that year. Further, the Company confirms that it incurred a negative revenue impact of $19.5 million for the financial year ended 31 December 2016 (2015: $0.0 million).

11:33 am
BE11:33am

CY18 results were noteworthy for the disturbing revelation of the extent of unexpected and previously denied profits and losses from client positions over a number of years.
Breakdown in trust between company and investors is a fundamental issue.
We were also surprised by the relatively weak number of new clients signed up in Q4'18 at 19,405 (CGf: 29,316).
Increased regulation means in our view Plus500 is a business in reverse.

DJ I'm sure Plus500 will put out some statement about how results will be ahead of market expectations and it'll slowly creep back up to the 1300 range, as they always do...
BE11:37am

Following the market P&L revelations and CY18 results, we have cut our ARPU and new client forecasts. We have also had to increase our AUAC assumptions.
Our EPS forecasts are slashed by 39% in CY19 and 32% in CY20.
Our new EPS forecasts are 37% below consensus (Bloomberg) in CY19, 42% below in CY20 and 36% below in CY21.

Catgotmytongue Any notes on Reckitt?
11:37 am
BE11:37am

A cocktail of declining earnings, ongoing regulatory reviews and questions about integrity mean we still see substantial downside from the current price.
The prospect of a take-private is a very, very distant one, in our opinion, requiring the shares to find a level significantly below the current price.
Our valuation is based on a CY20 target PE multiple of 6x, equating to a TP of 546p, 41% downside and an ETR of -34%. (Previous TP 1052p; CY20 8x PE target)
We reduce the target multiple to 6x (from 8x) due to the admission from management that it had historically omitted key financial information. Consequently, there is greater volatility to EPS than previously thought.

BE11:37am

We are pleased the company has apologized for this error but we think investors should also be aware that the CY17 & CY16 analyst presentations both stated that, "nil" revenues from Market PL were delivered in CY17, CY16 and CY15.
Management may state this was factually correct, i.e., client losses did not contribute positively to revenues. However, we believe investors are likely to feel aggrieved and possibly misled, particularly in light of the significant founders/PDMR and directors share sales in the recent past.
In Dec'18, 2.25m shares were sold at £13.90, netting £31.3m; in Sep'18, 9.39m shares were sold at £15.86 (£148.9m).

"RB has been on a well-established journey with a focussed, strategic evolution from a household cleaning company to a world leader in consumer health. Our most recent acquisition, MJN, has been a catalyst for RB2.0 - the creation of two end-to-end accountable Business Units. RB2.0 provides a platform for future growth and outperformance in each Business Unit. We remain committed to executing on this important project and will continue to evaluate opportunities to maximise shareholder value from RB2.0.

We are also under way in the search for a successor to Rakesh, whether internal or external, who will be a fit with the distinctive culture of RB and consistent with execution of RB2.0."

BE11:44am

Consensus doesn't really change tho. Here's Goldman.

BE11:44am

Organic growth - 4% in 4Q18 vs Vuma consensus of +3.3% and GSe of +4.5%
Reported sales - £3,339mn in 4Q18, inline with consensus of £3,330mn and GSe of £3,340mn
Adjusted operating profit - £3,358mn in FY18 (vs consensus of £3,355mn and GSe of £3,357mn), translating to a margin of 26.7% inline with consensus and GSe.
Adjusted diluted EPS - 339.9p in FY18, 4% ahead of consensus of 327.9p and GSe of 326.8p
Guidance - for FY19, management expect group organic revenue growth of 3-4% (vs current consensus expectations of 3.5%) and operating margins to be maintained (implying 26.7%) vs current consensus expectations for 27.1% (and GSe 27.0%).

BE11:45am

At group level, revenues and adjusted operating profits were inline with consensus expectations, with a beat on EPS driven by lower tax.
At divisional level, IFCN organic growth of 5% in 4Q 2018 fell short of consensus expectations of 6.6%. Growth was driven by strong growth in the US, offset be slower growth in China owing to the effects of the supply disruptions in 3Q impacting on-shelf product availability. Rest of Health (+3% LFL) came in ahead of expectations (of +2.1%), albeit management highlighted for its OTC business that a slower cold and flu season in December has left higher stock levels at retailers which will impact 1Q19 sales negatively. Hygiene Home also outperformed expectations with LFL growth of 4% (consensus +3%) and management cited growth was broad-based.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

Management’s guidance implies modest downgrades to consensus earnings expectations for 2019, all else equal, owing to the adjusted operating margin guide which is 40 bp below consensus.
RB is -8.1% over the last 3 months vs our European consumer staples coverage average of +2.6%.

joachim Sinclair effectively saying that RB 2.0 is a bridge to separation.
BE11:46am

And MOST.

VV75 @WayneJ, that is per partie, i.e. not enlargement of existing short position for any and all parties, excluding mm's ofcourse
BE11:46am

After the CEO's surprise retirement announcement in early
January, the stock fell back to 3 year lows on concerns for a weak Q4, a major margin reset and a potential change of strategic direction under a new CEO away from the planned split into two internal business units. In our Reset Me Not report we estimated that the market was anticipating a 150-250bps reset ahead of today. We believe these solid results, Chairman statement, LFL guidance, minireset and extended presentation later today provides significant reassurance.

11:46 am
BE11:47am

But still a show me story… Of course, to some the stock will remain a 'show me story' (not least with the reset and cautious Q1/Q2 guidance on Mead and Flu) and it is still easy to make the argument that the shares will remain in the penalty box. However, we believe today provides the required clarity and reassurance: enough to see the stock up despite a likely ~3% cut to consensus EPS. To us, the shares are offering very good value, with a growing operational momentum/turnaround and clear strategic optionality.

Pharma @wayneJ I think you are over-thinking this. I you are short Wirecard the hold on. If you are long Wirecard, then sell. If you are neither, buy popcorn.
Pharma *then*

11:50 am
BE11:50am

Reiterate BUY and 7,300 target price. Reckitt's strategic focus on faster growing, higher margin Health and Hygiene categories should lead to acceleration in organic sales growth to 4% in the medium-term. The Mead deal increased RB's focus on Health & Hygiene (80% of group net revenue post deal) and emerging markets (40% of group net revenues). In 2019, we expect a slow start due to a slow start to the cold and flu season, overhang from the baby food plant disruption in 3Q’18 and slower China growth. From 2019 onward we forecast moderate EBIT margin uplift (40-50bps) driven by category mix and cost savings driving 7% clean EPS CAGR over 2018-23E. The group’s reorganization in two discrete divisions – Health and Hygiene Home – creates long-term optionality for the group and could potentially lead to a break-up of the group, particularly if a large consumer health acquisition materializes. We expect leverage to fall to 2.0x net debt/EBITDA by 2019

BE11:50am

And, I dunno, Investec?

BE11:51am

We see little to excite bulls in the FY18 results, and expect the EPS consensus for FY19 to fall by c2%. We watch with interest for the appointment of Kapoor’s successor, with this being key, and continue to have concerns about structural pressures for the group’s OTC Health business in particular. Q119 is set to be soft, again, limiting share price upside in our view. We keep our 5600p/share target and Sell recommendation unchanged.

BE11:59am

Key questions have resurfaced: Issues that we think are at the foremost of
investors’ minds following the news include: i) uncertainty around the potential scope and financial implications of the investigation, ii) the risk of further legal action (law enforcement or shareholders), iii) how much risk is ‘priced-in’ to current valuations, and iv) what the possible implications for PFC’s franchise could be going forward.
New scenarios reveal wider spread of implied fair values: We revisit our
illustrative SFO scenario analysis and add contracts awarded in Iraq and Saudi Arabia worth over USD4bn to our original scope (which covered USD2bn of Kazakhstan awards). We reach a potential range of implied fair values of 355-830p and estimate that up to cUSD2.25bn in penalties and franchise impact may be ‘priced in’ to current valuations. To account for the increase (greater than 3x) in the amount of potential contracts under investigation, we revise our discount for the SFO investigation uncertainty in our valuation to 50% (from 20%). We also adjust EV/EBITDA multiples on PFC’s Engineering & Construction (E&C) business to 4.5x (from 5.8x).

11:59 am
BE11:59am

Is the case now a known unknown or an unknown unknown? The news
represents a material widening of our understanding of the case scope and introduces new uncertainties – e.g. we estimate that Saudi Arabia was PFC’s joint third largest market in the Middle East, since 2010 PFC booked 3-4x more contract awards (in USD) in Kuwait and Oman than Saudi Arabia.
FY2018 results: PFC reports its full-year results on a busy day for European OFS, 28 February. This is the next likely date for a qualitative update on the case.
Wider investigation risks dominating equity story, we downgrade to Hold: The potential expansion of the SFO case has the potential to overshadow the shareholder story over the coming years if a substantial fine is levied and the company franchise is impacted. We cut our TP to 380p and downgrade to Hold (from Buy).

BornCynic Thanks BE / ROTR
